Research article In situ engineering carbon-coated hydrotalcite-derived ZnxAlOy-C catalysts for efficient catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol Junling Xie Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Guyu Yin Investigation Data curation Xiaoyu Niu Methodology Investigation Yujun Zhu Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Investigation Conceptualization ⁎ Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University), Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University) Ministry of Education School of Chemistry and Materials Heilongjiang University Harbin 150080 PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University), Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenation (CTH) has been widely reported as an efficient, safe and green method for catalytic hydrogenation of biomass-derived platform molecules in recent years. In this work, we fabricated tunable Zn/Al molar ratio carbon-coated hydrotalcite-derived Zn-Al oxide composites (ZnxAlOy-C), where Isopropanol (IPA) served dual roles as hydrogen donor and reaction medium, to achieve selective hydrogenation of Furfural (FAL) into Furfuryl Alcohol (FOL). Under mild reaction conditions, the conversion of FAL and the selectivity of FOL can reach 92.0% and 93.8% over Zn2AlOy-C, respectively. Through analysis, the reasons for the high yield of FOL are that the surface carbon material effectively increases the specific surface area of the catalyst, enhances the adsorption capacity of the catalyst to the reactants, and more effectively promotes the migration of the reactants from the solution to the Zn-O-Al active site, while by adjusting the Zn/Al ratio, a suitable acid/base ratio is found to reduce the occurrence of side reactions and improve the selectivity. The current synthesis method provides an effective way to design carbon-containing composite catalysts with controllable catalytic application performance. Keywords Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Furfural Furfuryl alcohol Carbon-coated hydrotalcite-derived oxides ZnxAlOy-C Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalyzing and upgrading biomass-derived platform compounds into chemicals and fuels has attracted widespread attention in the past [1–3]. Furfural (FAL), a pivotal bio-renewable platform molecule obtained from biomass conversion [4]. FAL can synthesize a variety of chemical products by hydrogenation, oxidation, decarboxylation, acetylation and condensation, including furan (FAN), Furfuryl Alcohol (FOL), furoic acid, 1,5-pentanediol (PDOL), 2-methylfuran (2-MF), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and cyclopentanone [5–8]. Among them, FOL is a promising candidate for downstream hydrogenation products derived from FAL and has been garnered significant interest as a key raw material in the production of medical and sanitary fragrances [9–11]. Due to the important role of FOL in various industries, it is crucial to develop hydrogenation catalysts that can efficiently convert FAL into FOL [12,13]. Generally, the thermodynamic driving force manifests stronger hydrogenation propensity for unsaturated CC of FAL relative to the carbonyl CO group, whereas the inherent instability of FOL under hydrogenation conditions frequently leads to more prone to excessive hydrogenation, lowering the selectivity to FOL [14]. Copper chromium catalyst (CuCr2O4) is widely used in industrial production [15]. However, its use conditions require harsh conditions such as high temperature and high pressure, and it is easy to deactivate, and the Cr element is easy to cause environmental pollution and other problems. Therefore, it is necessary to design an efficient Cr-free catalyst to replace CuCr2O4 [16]. Recent advances have yielded numerous supported catalytic systems based on noble or transition metals for FAL hydrogenation in gaseous/liquid media, though their implementation demands severe operational constraints (elevated temperature/pressure) accompanied by inherent safety challenge [17,18]. H2 as a hydrogen source has excellent conversion efficiency, but the further development is limited by the transportation difficulty and the danger risk of H2 [19,20]. The Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenation (CTH) has gained significant attention as an effective pathway for FOL production, driven by its operational advantages under milder reaction conditions [21]. It is a favorite hydrogenation reduction method to use inexpensive alcohols, organic acids or hydrazine as hydrogen donors instead of H2 [22,23]. Organic alcohols are more convenient than organic acids due to their lower corrosiveness. Additionally, alcohols serve a dual role as both hydrogen source and solvent. Among the alcohols, Isopropanol (IPA) has been proven to be an effective hydrogen source for catalytic transfer hydrogenation due to its easier dehydrogenation. [24]. For transition metal catalysts, the CTH of FAL to FOL over Co [25], Ni [26,27], Cu-based [28] catalyst has high selectivity. Lewis acid-base catalysts, though exhibiting limited activity under traditional hydrogenation process, manifest significantly enhanced catalytic performance within CTH systems due to their tailored electronic interactions with hydrogen donors [29]. Li et al. [30] developed a suite of metallic hybrid catalysts for FAL and IPA hydrogen transfer reactions, with their mesoporous ZrPN composites exhibiting superior FOL selectivity. Ren et al. [31] prepared Co1Al2-MMO-200 via topological transformation of layered double hydroxides, achieving a reaction rate of 0.023 mol·g-1·h-1 in the CTH process of FAL. These researchers attributed this enhanced catalytic performance to the cooperative interaction between acid-base paired sites and the optimal balance of Lewis acid/base concentrations. Thus, the development of Lewis acid-base catalytic systems capable of facilitating FAL-to-FOL hydrogenation under mild operational parameters represents a critical research priority in sustainable catalysis [32]. Two-dimensional layered double hydroxides have become a promising solution for catalyzing the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation of furfural and other biomass-derived compounds in recent years [33,34]. The mixed metal oxides obtained by calcining LDHs can undergo structural topological transformation to adjust the dispersion and type of metal element, resulting in different acid-base properties [35,36], which significantly enhance their application in the field of catalysis. For example, Aswin et al. used a simple co-precipitation technique to synthesize molybdate intercalated copper–aluminum hydrotalcite (CAM) materials for applying in hydrogenation reaction [37]. Additionally, carbon materials have received significant interest because of their remarkable characteristics, including a high specific surface area, a porous structure, and a wealth of functional groups on their surface. Researchers have supported different metals on carbon materials to effectively improve the catalytic performance. For example, carbon materials as adsorbents can remove organic pollution molecules in water [38]. In this way, the carbon materials can be combined with a variety of catalysts to enhance the adsorption capacity of the catalyst to the reaction substrate, thereby improving the catalytic performance. Gong's research team developed a sulfonic acid-functionalized activated carbon-supported copper catalyst (Cu/AC-SO3H) that demonstrated superior catalytic activity for FAL hydrogenation to FOL in liquid-phase systems [39]. Our research team previously engineered a LaFeO3 perovskite catalyst via an in-situ carbon-templated synthesis approach. The presence of carbon vacancies facilitates the movement of reactants from the solution to the active sites of LaFeO3, thereby increasing the reaction rate of FAL to FOL [40]. Inspired by the above viewpoints, we proposed in situ preparation of carbon-coated ZnAl oxide catalysts using Zn-Al hydrotalcite with different Zn/Al ratio. On the one hand, the surface acidity and basicity on the hydrotalcite material can be tuned by altering the metal ratio. On the other hand, carbon materials can enhance the adsorption and mass transfer capacity for the reactants, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency. Based on description above, we prepared Zn-Al layered double hydroxide by co-precipitation method, an then mixed it with glucose and treated it in a nitrogen atmosphere to prepare carbon-coated ZnxAlOy-C (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) composite catalysts. Among them, Zn2AlOy-C catalyst showed excellent catalytic performance in the CTH reaction of FAL with IPA as the hydrogen source, and the TOF reached 197 min−1. The structure and active sites of the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts in the CTH process of FAL were analyzed in detail by various characterization methods. It was found that the adsorption and mass transfer of the carbon layer and the synergistic effect of the acid-base sites on the catalyst surface promoted the CTH reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O) was acquired from Tianli Chemical Limited Company in Tianjin, China. Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O) and glucose (C6H12O6) were sourced from Kermel Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. in Tianjin, China. Sodium carbonate anhydrous (Na2CO3) and 1-octanol were obtained from Tianli Chemical Reagent in Tianjin, China. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was purchased from Guangfu Technology Development Co., Ltd. in Tianjin, China. FAL was sourced from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., while isopropyl alcohol was obtained from Fuyu Fine Chemical Reagent in Tianjin, China. FOL was acquired from Zhanyun Chemical Reagent in Shanghai, China. All reagents maintained analytical-grade purity and were utilized without additional purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The ZnxAl hydrotalcites (ZnxAl-LDHs, Zn/Al molar ratios x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) were fabricated via coprecipitation method. In a representative synthesis: Stoichiometric quantities of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O were homogeneously dissolved in 50 mL deionized water to form precursor solution A. Solution B is prepared by dissolving sodium hydroxide and sodium carbonate in a 50 mL aqueous solution according to a specific stoichiometric ratio. Among them, the molar concentration of NaOH is 1.8 times that of all metal cations, and the molar concentration of Na2CO3 is twice that of Al3+. Under vigorous stirring conditions, solution B was slowly dripped into solution A. Stirring was continued for 2 h after completion of the addition, and the mixture was left to rest for 2 h and was filtered to obtain a solid product. And then washing was repeated three times for the product with the distilled water until the filtrate was neutral. Each of the resulting ZnxAl-LDHs (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) samples was placed in a Teflon autoclave, to which 50 mL of glucose solution was added, and then the mixture was hydrothermally treated at 150 °C for 10 h. After falling to room temperature, the precipitate was collected, washed extensively with water and ethanol, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the precursors were heated at 500 °C for 2 h in nitrogen atmosphere to form carbon-coated mixed metal oxides, called ZnxAlOy-C. For comparison, each of the ZnxAl-LDHs (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) samples was directly hydrothermally treated at 150 °C for 10 h. At the same time, ZnO, Al2O3 and ZnOC and Al2O3 C precursors without carbon and Al or Zn sources were synthesized respectively and hydrothermally treated under the same conditions. In the same way, the precursors obtained after hydrothermal treatment were heated at 500 °C for 2 h in nitrogen atmosphere to form mixed metal oxides, named as ZnxAlOy, ZnO, Al2O3, ZnOC and Al2O3 C, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The structure and morphology of the catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD), thermal analyzer, Raman spectroscopy, nitrogen adsorption and desorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) element mapping. The contents of Zn and Al were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). The surface atomic concentration and chemical state data were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the catalysts were characterized by temperature programmed desorption of ammonia/carbon dioxide/IPA (NH3/CO2/IPA-TPD) and in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The specific description can be found in the Supplementary Material. 2.4 Hydrogenation of FAL to FOL The Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenation (CTH) process of FAL was performed in a 100 mL polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-lined stainless steel reactor, integrated with precision temperature control and magnetic agitation systems. The catalytic system comprised 50.0 mg catalyst, 252.5 mg (2.63 mmol) FAL, and 15 mL IPA as both hydrogen donor and solvent. Remove the air in the reactor with N2 for 5–6 times, the reaction was performed at 150–180 °C under 300 rpm magnetic stirring for 1–4 h. Upon completion of the catalytic reaction, the reactor underwent cooling to ambient temperature (25 ± 2 °C). A precisely measured amount of 1-octanol was introduced as an internal calibrant to the reaction mixture, followed by using a BFRL SP-3420A gas chromatograph (HP-5 capillary column: 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) equipped with flame ionization detection (FID) to analyze the concentrations of FAL and FOL. Additionally, the products were also identified by GC–MS (Thermo Fisher, ISQLT). In the recycling experiments, the catalyst was washed with water and IPA following centrifugation, then dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C prior to being used again. The specific calculation formula can be found in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of ZnxAlOy-C 3.1.1 XRD analysis As shown in Fig. S1, the XRD patterns confirm that ZnxAl-LDHs (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) precursors are successfully synthesized by co-precipitation method. Fig. 1 A displays the XRD patterns for ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. All the catalysts exhibit ZnO-related diffraction peaks (PDF# 75–1526), which are very weak, indicating that the crystallinity of the catalysts is low. And no peak of Al2O3 is observed, indicating that alumina oxide may exist in an amorphous state in ZnxAlOy-C. With the increase of Zn content, the half peak width of the (100) crystal plane attributed to ZnO becomes narrowed gradually, indicating that the crystallinity of the catalysts is gradually increasing. Although no peaks for Al2O3 are observed in the XRD patterns, the diffraction peaks of ZnO do not shift to low or high angle direction. This indicates that Al does not enter the zinc oxide lattice and is still in an amorphous state alumina, and the two form the mixed metal oxides. Meanwhile, two weak broad peaks are observed around 2θ of 23.3 and 44°, corresponding to the amorphous carbon and the (101) crystal plane of graphitic carbon, respectively [41]. As the Zn content rises, the former peak gradually intensifies, suggesting that the amount of amorphous carbon also increases, while the amount of graphitic carbon correspondingly decreases [42,43]. From this, it can be concluded that the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts prepared are the composites made of zinc-aluminum oxides and carbon with different degree of graphitization. 3.1.2 Analysis of carbon content In order to determine the carbon content of the fabricated catalysts, TG-DTA analysis was conducted under an air atmosphere, with the outcomes depicted in Fig. 2 . The Zn2AlOy sample (Fig. 2F) only shows slight weight loss (2.2 %) before 300 °C, possibly due to the elimination of surface physically adsorbed water. After 300 °C, there is no weight loss, indicating the formation of stable oxide for Zn2AlOy. The TG analysis of ZnxAlOy-C reveals two distinct mass loss regions (Fig. 2A–E), with the initial phase below approximately 300 °C corresponding to desorption of physisorbed surface water molecules. After 400 °C, the catalysts lose almost half of their mass, and the DTA curves show sharp exothermic peaks, which are related to the oxidation of the carbon in the catalyst. The catalyst's carbon content was determined by quantifying the weight loss, with the corresponding results presented in Table 1 . Evidently, with the increase in Zn content, the weight loss rates of the catalysts are 41.2 %, 45.9 %, 48.0 %, 48.2 %, and 49.3 %, increasing the carbon content gradually, demonstrating that Zn species is in favor of the carbonation of glucose. The ICP-OES results show that the Zn/Al ratios in the ZnxAlOy-C samples (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) are 0.42, 0.83, 1.76, 2.15, and 2.44 with increasing x value, respectively (Table 1). According to the ICP test results, the actual Zn/Al atomic ratio of the ZnxAlOy-C catalyst is somewhat lower than the theoretical value intended during the preparation process. 3.1.3 Raman spectra analysis In order to further study the structure property of the catalysts, the as-prepared samples were characterized by Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra of all the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts are shown in Fig. 1B. Each Raman spectrum reveals two prominent overlapping features: A G-band centered at 1580–1600 cm-1 corresponding to the vibrational modes of sp2 carbon atoms in defect-free graphene sheets, and a D-band represents the breathing mode of ring or defect in graphitic lattice [44]. The peak area ratio of the D-band to the G-band (ID/IG) was usually used to assess the defect and degree of graphitization in carbon materials. A smaller ID/IG value indicates a higher degree of graphitization [45]. The fitting curves of Raman peaks and the results of fitting peak area are shown in Fig. S2 and Table. S1. The ID/IG values are 1.25 (Zn0.5AlOy-C), 1.72 (ZnAlOy-C), 2.05 (Zn2AlOy-C), 2.76 (Zn3AlOy-C) and 2.96 (Zn4AlOy-C). The value increases with the Zn content, suggesting that the graphitization degree of carbon in the catalysts decreases as the Zn content rises. This trend is in agreement with the XRD results. Thus, the results indicate that more defective carbon is formed in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts with the increase of Zn content, which may affect the adsorption performance of the catalysts on the organic molecules. Under the same experimental conditions, ZnO-C and Al2O3-C samples were prepared and subjected to XRD and Raman spectroscopy testing. As shown in Fig. S3, the ID/IG ratio of the ZnO-C sample (2.42) is higher than that of the Al2O3-C sample (1.80), indicating that the presence of ZnO alone is detrimental to the graphitization of carbon, while aluminum oxide can promote the graphitization of carbon materials. 3.1.4 N2 adsorption–desorption results The porous characteristics and specific surface area of the synthesized catalysts were systematically investigated through N2 adsorption–desorption analysis, the findings are presented in Fig. 1C and Table 1. The catalysts Zn0.5AlOy-C and ZnAlOy-C display type IV isotherms with an H4 hysteresis loop, whereas Zn2AlOy-C, Zn3AlOy-C, and Zn4AlOy-C exhibit type IV isotherms accompanied by an H3 hysteresis loop. These observations suggest that all catalysts possess mesoporous structures, but their pore morphology evolves from slit-like to sheet-like with increasing Zn content. This transition is likely attributed to the progressive rise in the Zn concentration, which reduces the graphitization degree of the catalysts and consequently increases the degree of surface defects. Are presented in Table 1, Zn2AlOy has a specific surface area of just 72 m2∙g−1. However, the surface area increases with the amount of Zn, which is measured to be 185 m2∙g−1 for Zn0.5AlOy-C, 247 m2∙g−1 for ZnAlOy-C, 260 m2∙g−1 for Zn2AlOy-C, 270 m2∙g−1 for Zn3AlOy-C, and reaches 286 m2∙g−1 for Zn4AlOy-C. This increase is directly related to the carbon content, indicating that the surface area is primarily contributed by carbon, as illustrated in Fig. 1D. Compared with Zn2AlOy, the pore size is much larger for ZnxAlOy-C samples and the pore size distribution range is wider. Moreover, the pore property is also different among these ZnxAlOy-C samples. This change may be because the graphitization degree of carbon in the samples is different with the increase of Zn content, which in turn induces a trend of initial increase followed by decrease in the pore size and pore volume of the catalysts. Among all the catalysts, the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst has a large specific surface area (260 m2∙g−1) and the largest pore volume (0.5740 cm3∙g−1), indicating that different Zn/Al addition amounts can lead to varying degrees of graphitization, changing the physicochemical properties of the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. 3.2 SEM and TEM analysis The morphological and textural characteristics of ZnxAlOy-C were systematically examined through the images of SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 3 , the Zn0.5AlOy-C catalyst exhibits a spherical and bulk structure, with a small amount of lamellar structure attached to its surface. The surface carbon content of the sample is close to 50 %, and the Raman spectrum shows that the Zn0.5AlOy-C sample has a high degree of graphitization and a low specific surface area, resulting in the final appearance of this morphology. With the gradual increase of Zn content, the layered structure on the catalyst surface becomes increasingly regular. The transition from slit pores to sheet pores is achieved by layering nanosheets, which aligns with the findings from N2 adsorption–desorption results. Comprehensive structural characterization of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst was performed using TEM images. As presented in Fig. 4 A, it reveals a disordered carbonaceous matrix enveloping the catalyst surface, with the enlarged TEM image (Fig. 4B) confirming the amorphous nature of this carbon layer through the absence of lattice fringes, a characteristic feature of non-graphitic carbon structures. The TEM images show that the outer layer of the catalyst exhibits disordered carbon. Fig. 4C and D–G display the HAADF-STEM images along with the corresponding elemental EDS mapping of the catalyst. The EDS mapping in Fig. 4D and E indicates that the Zn and Al elements are well dispersed, while the C element in Fig. 4F shows a denser distribution, indicating that the disordered carbon encapsulates the zinc-aluminum oxide. The thermal analysis results also confirm that approximately 50 % carbon in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. 3.3 Surface properties of catalysts 3.3.1 XPS analysis To further determine elemental composition and surface properties the catalyst, XPS was conducted on the synthesized Zn2AlOy and ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. Based on the data analysis from Fig. 5 A, the elements Zn, Al, O, and C for the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts are detected on its surface. Whereas the surface amount of elements Zn, Al and O is significantly higher on Zn2AlOy than that on the Zn2AlOy-C catalysts, especially for Zn and O. Moreover, the carbon content on ZnxAlOy-C catalysts is approximately 53–63 %, accounting for more than half of the catalyst. This indicates that the catalyst's surface is mainly made up of carbon material. This suggests hydrotalcite derived Zn-Al oxides are coated with carbon. Furthermore, the data in Table 2 show that the surface contents of Zn and Al on Zn2AlOy are 28.08 % and 14.98 %, respectively, and the surface Zn/Al ratio of 1.87 is slightly smaller than the bulk experimental results. Evidently, the surface Zn content is very low on the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts, and the surface Al content also decreases, but the decrease is much smaller than the surface Zn element. With the increase of Zn content, the Zn/Al ratio in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts gradually increases, but the Zn/Al ratio on the surface is also much lower than that of the corresponding bulk Zn/Al ratio. In conjunction with the preceding experimental findings, it is proved that when the Zn content is small, the Zn element is wrapped in the carbon material in the form of ZnO, while most of the Al element is dispersed in the carbon layer. With the addition of Zn, the surface Zn/Al ratio is also gradually increasing, and the Zn element in the surface carbon layer is also increasing. This indicates that most of the catalyst surface is composed of carbon materials, and Al oxide is preferentially accumulated in the surface carbon layer. By analyzing the Raman spectra of ZnO-C and Al2O3-C (Fig. S3B), we believe that both Al and Zn elements play important roles in the degree of graphitization of the carbon material, but Al is the main element that promotes the degree of graphitization. From Fig. 5B, it is found that the peak at 73.8 eV corresponds well to the binding energy of Al 2p, which is identified as the standard alumina peak [46]. However, the corresponding diffraction peaks of alumina is not observed in the XRD patterns. The characterization results from both XRD and XPS corroborate each other, indicating that the aluminum species are mainly amorphous alumina phase in ZnxAlOy-C. The Zn 2p XPS spectra are depicted in Fig. 5C. It is evident that the two distinct peaks appear at 1021.7 (Zn 2p3/2) and 1044.8 eV (Zn 2p1/2), characteristic of ZnO [46]. As shown in the O 1s spectra (Fig. 5D), the deconvolution results reveal two characteristic peaks for Zn2AlOy at 530.2 eV (assigned to lattice oxygen, OⅠ) and 532.0 eV (attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species, OⅡ). Notably, the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts display an additional spectral feature at 533.04 eV, which corresponds to the oxygen-containing functional groups (CO, CO and carboxyl) on the surface of the carbon material (Fig. S4) [47–49]. The C 1s XPS spectrum was employed to assess the graphitization degree of the carbon materials in the catalysts, with the results illustrated in Fig. 6 . This spectrum can be deconvoluted into six distinct peaks, corresponding to sp2-C (284.1 eV), defect sp3-C (285.1 eV), CO (286.3 eV), CO (287.4 eV), COOR (288.7 eV), and π-π* resonance (289.8 eV) [50]. Typically, the Csp3/Csp2 ratio serves as an indicator of the carbon graphitization level. According to the data analysis in Table 2, the amount of graphite carbon (Csp2) on the surface gradually decreases with increasing Zn content and decreasing Al amount, while the amount of defect carbon (Csp3) gradually increases. As shown in Table S2, the most of C species are graphite carbon and defective carbon, and the distribution number of other C species is close. At the same time, based on the Raman spectra, linear fitting graph between ID/IG and Sp3/Sp2 for each catalyst was plotted, indicating a close linear relationship between these two parameters (Fig. 6D). It can be concluded from the data that as the Zn content increases, the defects degree of C also gradually increases. This further suggests that the Al element can be a significant factor in enhancing the graphitization degree of the carbon materials in the ZnxAlOy-C samples. Moreover, the catalyst surface is abundant in oxygen-containing functional groups (Fig. S4), which likely facilitate the adsorption of reactants (FAL and IPA) onto the catalyst surface, thereby enabling more efficient transport of these reactants to the active sites. 3.3.2 Analysis of surface acid and base properties The impacts of varying Zn content on the surface acidity and basicity of the catalysts were systematically studied by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis. For comparison, ZnO and Al2O3 samples were also tested in the same way. As shown in Fig. 7 B, the ZnxAlOy samples show a weak NH3 desorption peak (the scale is very small size) in 25–120 °C in NH3-TPD curves, indicating that the catalysts have poor weak acidic sites. Quantitative analysis of desorption peak integration shows the Zn2AlOy sample has the greatest number of acidic sites (31.7 μmol∙g−1) among this series of ZnxAlOy samples in Table S3. The surface basicity characteristics of the ZnxAlOy catalysts were comprehensively characterized through CO2-TPD analysis. Fig. 7D shows the CO2 desorption peaks of the ZnxAlOy samples within the range of 25–500 °C, revealing the coexistence of weak-to-medium strength base sites (25–250 °C) and high-strength basic centers (300–500 °C) on the samples. Table S3 displays the basic amount of the synthesized samples. Additionally, the acid amount on the ZnxAlOy-C series catalysts (222–248 μmol/g) is significantly higher than that on the synthesized ZnxAlOy samples, as listed in Fig. 7A and Table S4. The presence of oxygen-containing functional groups such as COOH and OH on the surface of C materials in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts may be the reason for the higher NH3 adsorption value confirmed by the FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S4). Moreover, the basic amount also decreases with increasing Zn content on the ZnxAlOy-C samples (Fig. 7C), and it is much lower than that of the corresponding ZnxAlOy samples. These results demonstrate that ZnxAlOy is inside the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts and the carbon is coated outside, making it difficult for CO2 molecules to interact with ZnxAlOy due to the acidic oxygen-containing functional groups of the C layer in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. Therefore, we believe that the acidity and basicity of ZnxAlOy-C surface is mainly derived from ZnxAlOy. 3.4 Activity evaluation towards CTH of FAL 3.4.1 Catalytic activity over Zn2AlOy and ZnxAlOy-C The catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FAL to FOL was investigated under 170 °C for 3 h, utilizing IPA as both solvent and hydrogen donor. As summarized in Table 3 , the blank control experiment (entry 1) demonstrates negligible FAL conversion (10.1 %) in the absence of catalyst. Moreover, the CTH of FAL to FOL was also conducted on ZnxAlOy catalysts, with the results presented in Table S5. Obviously, the catalytic activity of all ZnxAlOy samples is poor. And as the Zn/Al ratio increases, the FAL conversion gradually decreases as follow: Zn0.5AlOy (40.3 %) > ZnAlOy (31.0 %) > Zn2AlOy (22.8 %) > Zn3AlOy (20.5 %) > Zn4AlOy (17.3 %). However, the selectivity for FOL initially increases and then decreases with the increasing Zn/Al ratio: Zn2AlOy (43.9 %) > ZnAlOy (40.4 %) > Zn0.5AlOy (29.8 %) > Zn3AlOy (20.0 %) > Zn4AlOy (7.45 %). In contrast, the catalytic activity of ZnxAlOy-C is significantly improved (Table 4), and the conversion of FAL exhibits increasing first and then decreasing trend with increasing Zn amount. Among them, the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst presents the highest CTH performance, reaching 92.0 % FAL conversion and 93.8 % FOL selectivity. Here, GC–MS analysis was used to identify the products besides FOL. As shown in Fig. S5, the by-product (RT = 3.26 min) is identified as isopropyl-furfuryl ether derived from the reaction between FOL and IPA (Scheme S1). Moreover, the solution after the reaction does not exhibit dark turbidity, indicating that FAL or FOL do not undergo deep polymerization to form resinized polymers during the reaction (Fig. S6). In this study, only the concentrations of FAL and FOL were analyzed quantitatively by GC method. The activity stability of Zn2AlOy-C catalyst was tested under the optimum reaction conditions. After three tests, the activity decreases slightly (Fig. 8 A), which can be attributed to the fact that the organic molecules cover some active sites of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst [51,52]. In addition, the possible leaching of active components during the liquid phase reaction of the composite catalyst was evaluated. Fig. S7compares the change of FOL yield on the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst before and after hot filtration separation. After the removal of Zn2AlOy-C, the FOL yield does not change, indicating that the active metal sites are not leached in the reaction solution. The TOF value was estimated based on the yield of FOL and the Al content on the surface of the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts (Table 3). The order of TOF values from high to low is Zn2AlOy-C (197 min−1) > Zn3AlOy-C (126 min−1) > Zn4AlOy-C (119 min−1) > ZnAlOy-C (61 min−1) > Zn0.5AlOy-C (39 min−1). Obviously, the TOF value of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst is the highest, which is much higher than that of other samples, indicating the beneficial effect of the appropriate addition of Zn in the mixed metal oxide carbon composites. The reaction rates of these catalysts were also calculated, Zn2AlOy-C (16.0 mmol∙g−1∙h−1) > Zn3AlOy-C (9.97 mmol∙g−1∙h−1) > Zn4AlOy-C (9.67 mmol∙g−1∙h−1) > ZnAlOy-C (9.36 mmol∙g−1∙h−1) > Zn0.5AlOy-C (8.58 mmol∙g−1∙h−1). Among them, the reaction rate on Zn2AlOy-C is 4 times that on Zn2AlOy (3.95 mmol∙g−1∙h−1), indicating that the in-situ generated carbon-coated mixed metal oxide catalyst has better catalytic performance. In addition, the catalysts reported in the literature for the CTH of FAL to FOL were summarized in Table S6. Compared with these studies, the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst prepared in this paper is superior to most reported catalysts under similar conditions. 3.4.2 Effect of reaction conditions on activity over Zn2AlOy-C To obtain the reaction conditions for optimal FOL yield, the influences of reaction time and temperature on the CTH performance on Zn2AlOy-C were carried out. As shown in Fig. 8B, with a gradual increase in reaction temperature, the FAL conversion significantly increases from 54.6 % at 150 °C to 92 % at 170 °C, while the selectivity also increases from 77.6 % to 93.8 %. However, as the temperature reaches to 180 °C, there is not a notable increase in the conversion of FAL, while the selectivity for FOL decreases. This decline in selectivity may be attributed to the fact that higher temperature can lead to the continued hydrogenation of FOL or the formation of other byproducts, ultimately reducing the selectivity for FOL. Therefore, 170 °C is the optimal reaction temperature. The impact of reaction time on the CTH activity was examined on Zn2AlOy-C (Fig. 8C). Initially, both the conversion of FAL and the selectivity for FOL increase with time. However, when the reaction is prolonged to 4 h, the main product, FOL, may undergo further hydrogenation or pyrolysis to form additional by-products, leading to a decrease in its selectivity. Therefore, the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst possesses the best catalytic hydrogen transfer activity when reacted at 170 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 3 h, on which the FAL conversion is 92 % and the selectivity of the target product FOL is 93.8 %. We also tested the influences of the reaction conditions such as reaction temperature, reaction time and hydrogen donor on the activity at low conversion of FAL. As depicted in Fig. S8A and B, the results are consistent with that at high conversion of FAL (Fig. 8B and C). This indicates that the CHT of FAL to FOL under our experimental conditions is the intrinsic activity of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst itself. 3.4.3 Influence of hydrogen donor In the CTH process, the solvent acts as the hydrogen donor. Literature has shown that the solvent effect can have an impact on the reaction. Therefore, we studied the CTH process of FAL to FOL over the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst by using various H-donor, including methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), propanol (ProOH), IPA (2-ProOH), n-butanol (n-BuOH), tert-butanol (2-BuOH), and cyclohexanol (adronal), with the results presented in Fig. 8D. Obviously, secondary alcohols exhibit better catalytic performance than primary alcohols. For example, the conversion and selectivity using 2-ProOH are 92.0 % and 93.8 %, respectively, both of which are higher than those using ProOH at 70.0 % and 62.7 %. Similarly, the conversion and selectivity of 2-BuOH are 67.5 % and 90.0 %, respectively, which are also higher than those of n-BuOH at 43.3 % and 57.6 %. The hydrogen bonds between the CO in FAL and the hydroxyl group in alcohol help activate the FAL molecules, so alcohol as a hydrogen donor has good activity [53,54]. Relative to primary alcohols (such as methanol, ethanol, and 1-propanol), secondary alcohols demonstrate higher catalytic activity, likely due to their lower reduction potential. This difference can stem from the fact that the β-H in secondary alcohols is more readily eliminated than that in primary alcohols. Additionally, when using 2-buOH as a hydrogen donor, the conversion of FAL is only 43.3 %, which is much lower than the conversion when IPA is used as the hydrogen donor. In other words, the conversion of FAL decreases markedly as the number of carbon atoms in the alcohol increases. This may be attributed to the longer carbon chain causing a more pronounced negative spatial effect, making the diffusion of substrate molecules more difficult. Moreover, when using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen donor, the conversion of FAL and the selectivity for FOL are only 16.9 % and 12.2 %, respectively, which are quite poor. This is probably attributed to the weak interaction between the catalyst and cyclohexanol, which is caused by the steric hindrance, high viscosity, and high boiling point of cyclohexanol [55,56]. The similar results are obtained when controlling the low conversion of FAL by adding more FAL to investigate the effects of various H-donors, as presented in Fig. S8C. Hence, IPA is selected as the best hydrogen donor for theCTH of FAL to FOL. 3.5 In situ FT-IR spectra of FAL and IPA adsorption The adsorption of FAL and IPA on catalyst surface was investigated through in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy. The catalyst was pretreated at 200 °C in N2 atmosphere to eliminate physically adsorbed contaminants prior to analysis. FAL (or IPA) was added into the reaction cell at 30 °C for 60 min to carry out FAL (or IPA) adsorption at different time intervals. 3.5.1 Adsorption of FAL Fig. S9 depicts the adsorption behavior of FAL on different catalysts. For the Zn2AlOy sample, the peaks at 1279 and 1154 cm−1 are assigned to the bending vibrations of CH and the stretching vibrations of CO and CC in the inner ring, respectively [57]. The vibrational peak observed at 1750 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of the CO bond [58]. In addition, the peaks at the lower wavenumbers of 1689 and 1673 cm−1 belong to the CO bond stretching vibration peak, which is caused by the interaction between the surface of the catalyst and the CO bond. As shown in Fig. 9 A, the ν(CO) vibration band of FAL molecule has a slight red shift at 1698 and 1683 cm−1 on the Zn2AlOy sample compared with the gas phase FAL. For the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts, the ν(CO) vibration bands exhibit a significant red shift to 1689 and 1675 cm−1. This red shift indicates that FAL molecules are adsorbed on the surfaces of the Zn2AlOy and ZnxAlOy-C catalysts through the ν(CO) bond. The Zn2AlOy exhibits distinct vibrational bands in the FT-IR spectra, with characteristic bands at 1474 and 1394 cm-1 corresponding to ν(CC) stretching modes of FAL. Generally, the CC bond exhibits bridge-type adsorption on the surface of the catalyst, which leads to the absence of ν(CC). However, on the surface of our prepared catalysts, both ν(CC) and ν(CO) are detectable, indicating that only ν(CO) is activated on the surface of ZnxAlOy-C. The minor variations in these two bands imply that the furan ring and the (CC) bond are not adsorbed onto the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. Therefore, the difference in catalytic activity may be attributed to different adsorption modes on the catalyst surface. On the Zn2AlOy catalyst, both CC and CO bonds may be in a co-adsorption mode. This adsorption mode causes different reaction paths of FAL on the active sites, which eventually leads to side reactions and product diversification, resulting in low FAL conversion and FOL selectivity. For the ZnxAlOy-C catalyst, the furan ring in the FAL interacts with the carbon layer in the catalyst through the π-π interaction on the surface of the ZnxAlOy-C catalyst. At the same time, the selective adsorption and activation of CO bonds on the catalyst surface enhance the conversion of FAL to FOL. 3.5.2 Adsorption of IPA The adsorption of IPA on the surfaces of Zn2AlOy and ZnxAlOy-C series catalysts was also studied using in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy. For gaseous IPA molecules, a peak at 1162 cm−1 at room temperature corresponds to the CO stretching vibration, as depicted in Fig. S10. On the Zn2AlOy sample, peaks at 2974 and 2888 cm−1 are likely attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the CH groups (ν(CH3)) in IPA. Additionally, characteristic peaks of ν(CO) are observed at 1161 and 1129 cm−1, along with an OH vibration peak around 3350 cm−1 [59]. On the ZnxAlOy-C series catalysts, after adsorption of IPA at 30 °C (Fig. 9B), the characteristic peak of ν(CO) is found to gradually redshift from 1162 cm−1 to 1159 cm−1, indicating significant activated adsorption of IPA on Zn2AlOy and ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. Especially, the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst exhibits a stronger adsorption capacity for IPA than Zn2AlOy, which may be one of the reasons for its better hydrogenation performance. As illustrated in Fig. 10 A, some experiments on IPA adsorption were performed on Zn2AlOy at various temperatures to investigate its activation and hydrogen supply processes. The catalyst was pre-treated at 220 °C in a nitrogen environment to remove water and other impurities from its surface. Subsequently, IPA was slowly added to the reaction cell at 40 °C, and the temperature was raised to 220 °C. Measurements were taken after each temperature point for 30 min of adsorption. On the Zn2AlOy catalyst, the ν(CO) bond experiences a gradual red shift, moving from 1167 cm−1 to 1162 cm−1 as the temperature rises from 40 °C to 220 °C. Particularly, a new vibrational peak is observed at 1668 cm−1 at 180 °C, which is associated with the ν(CO) bond. This may indicate the formation of the intermediate containing-CO due to IPA dehydrogenation at higher temperatures. Furthermore, the negative peak observed at 3734 cm−1 is believed to the result from the interaction between hydroxyl groups in IPA and the surface of the Zn2AlOy catalyst, forming hydrogen bonds. Additionally, the mass spectrometry signals recorded in IPA-TPD of Zn2AlOy sample are shown in Fig. 10B, and only the signal of H2 is observed, which further indicates the successful dehydrogenation of IPA on the surface of the Zn2AlOy catalyst at high temperature. Furthermore, the adsorption of the mixture of FAL + IPA and the potential reaction pathways were investigated on the Zn2AlOy catalyst (Fig. 10C). The characteristic adsorption peak intensity of the mixture between 1700–1500 and 1500–1000 cm−1 is basically the same, and the characteristic peaks belonging to the-CH3 group at 3000–2850 cm−1 completely disappear. This indicates that these two molecules can gradually react to form intermediate products with the increase of temperature. To verify the true catalytic active sites, we also conducted in situ infrared spectroscopy tests for the adsorption of FAL and IPA at room temperature on ZnO and Al2O3 samples for different times. From Fig. 11 , it can be seen that the pure ZnO surface does not adsorb FAL and IPA, while the Al2O3 sample surface does adsorb both FAL and IPA, which indirectly proves that Al oxide should be the catalytic active sites. 3.6 Investigations on reaction mechanism over Zn2AlOy-C catalyst The Zn2AlOy-C catalysts composited of carbon-coated Zn-Al oxides show the superior catalytic performance in the CTH of FAL to FOL. In conjunction with the characterization results, it is inferred that the enhanced activity of Zn2AlOy-C compared to Zn2AlOy is due to the improved physiochemical properties of Zn2AlOy-C, resulting from the formation of in-situ carbon and proper acidity and basicity on its surface. Given that the primary distinction between the Zn2AlOy-C and Zn2AlOy catalysts is the presence of carbon, we speculate that the enhanced catalytic activity is likely attributable to the carbon in Zn2AlOy-C. To elucidate the role of carbon in the catalytic reaction, a series of experiments were conducted. First, carbon materials with different ID/IG ratios were prepared. The ID/IG ratio of the Carbon-180/10 sample is close to Zn2AlOy-C (Fig. S11), indicating that the graphitization degree of carbon is similar in both the two samples. After mechanically grinding and mixing Zn2AlOy and the Carbon-180/10 catalyst in the same mass ratio as Zn2AlOy-C, the activity test reveals a FAL conversion of 27.8 % and only 8 % selectivity to FOL, which are significantly lower than those of Zn2AlOy-C. After comparing and evaluating the catalytic activity of individual carbon materials in the FAL hydrogenation process (Table S7), it is found that its activity is almost negligible, which can be compared with the blank control experiment without catalyst. Therefore, it is confirmed that carbon materials lack intrinsic activity in the CTH of FAL process. Moreover, the simple mixture of carbon and Zn2AlOy does not provide the extra activity from the carbon sample. In addition, the furan ring in FAL and IPA can adsorb on the carbon layer by π-π interactions based on the structure of carbon layer in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts, improving their mass transfer efficiency (Figs. 9 and 10). Moreover, the specific surface area of the Zn2AlOy-C (260 m2·g−1) catalyst is 3.6 times that of the Zn2AlOy sample (72 m2·g−1) (Fig. S12). Thus, the results indicate that more defective carbon is formed in the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts with the increase of Zn content, which may affect the adsorption performance of the catalysts on the organic molecules. Furthermore, Al oxide species and Zn oxide are dispersed in the carbon layer according to XPS results. As a result, the carbon material on the surface aids in enhancing the adsorption of the two reactants onto the catalyst surface and facilitates their movement to the active sites. Compared with the inherent limitations of single metal oxides in terms of conversion and product selectivity, the composite catalyst system constructed by mixed metal oxides and carbon-based materials exhibits significantly enhanced catalytic efficiency. For these catalysts, the difference in surface acidity and basicity is a key factor affecting the activity. So, we think on ZnxAlOy-C catalyst surface, the Al2O3 component provides abundant Lewis acid-base pairs (Al3+–O2–), which provide anchoring sites for the adsorption of reactants. Secondly, the introduction of Zn species can adjust the surface acidity and basicity of ZnxAlOy. The acidic sites (Al3+) on the catalyst surface are conducive to the adsorption of FAL and IPA, while the basic sites (O2–) promote the dehydrogenation of IPA. These characteristics have obvious compatibility with the structural characteristics of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst, and such acid-base synergistic effect may lead to a significant increase in catalytic activity. Through the activity test, we found that the conversion rate of FAL gradually decreases with the increase of Zn content in the ZnxAlOy catalysts. The conversion rate on the Zn0.5AlOy sample is the largest, and the Al content is the most. Therefore, we believe that the activity should be related to Al oxide, and the catalytic activity data (Table S8) on ZnO and Al2O3 also verify the opinion. Combined with XRD and XPS results, the catalyst is mainly composed of mixed metal oxides (ZnO-Al2O3) and carbon. Through the previous XPS results, when the Zn/Al ratio is small, the Zn element is encapsulated in the carbon material in the form of ZnO, and most of the Al element is dispersed in the carbon layer. The surface of the catalyst is mainly composed of Zn-O-Al conjugated acid-base pairs, and the surface acidity of the catalyst is mainly provided by Al3+. When the Zn/Al ratio gradually increases, the XRD results show that the catalyst mainly exists in the form of ZnO species, and the surface gradually changes into ZnOZn acid-base pairs. At this time, the surface acidity of the catalyst is provided by ZnO. Thus, the ZnOZn acid-base pair results in a decrease in catalytic activity due its poor acidity and basicity. In addition, combined with the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD results of the synthesized ZnO and Al2O3 samples (Fig. S13), the acidity of Al2O3 (100 μmol∙g−1) is much greater than that of ZnO (14 μmol∙g−1), and the basicity of Al2O3 (248 μmol∙g−1) is also much greater than ZnO. Therefore, we believe that the acidity and basicity of the ZnxAlOy-C catalysts mainly come from Al species, while the addition of Zn can adjust the acidity and basicity. The acid/base ratio was calculated to 0.08, 0.15, 0.41, 0.32 and 0.29 on the ZnxAlOy series surfaces with different Zn contents (Table S3). It has been observed that the acid/base ratio initially rises and then falls as the Zn content increases. The results show that the Zn2AlOy sample has the highest acid/base ratio. It is evident that by adjusting the metal element ratio of the LDHs precursors and adding carbon materials, the acidic and basic sites on the surface of these ZnxAlOy-C catalysts can be effectively fine-tuned. As shown in Fig. 12 A, the relationship is analyzed between the TOF and the acid-base ratio was analyzed on the catalysts. It can be seen from the diagram that the acid/base ratio on the catalyst surface is significantly positively correlated with the TOF values. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 12B, we also analyzed the relationship between FOL selectivity and acid/base ratio on the ZnxAlOy. A linear correlation has been identified between the acid/base ratio and the selectivity of FOL. As the acid/base ratio increases, the selectivity for FOL also rises, exerting a pronounced influence on FOL selectivity. These findings suggest that an optimal distribution of acid and base sites on the catalyst surface, working in synergy, can significantly enhance the selectivity towards FOL. This finding provides a clear structural optimization direction for the design of efficient CTH catalysts. Therefore, we tried to propose the CTH reaction pathways of FAL to FOL on Zn2AlOy-C catalyst (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the furan ring of FAL is combined with the carbon layer on the on Zn2AlOy-C catalyst surface due to π-π interaction, while the oxygen atom in the CO group of FAL facilitates its adsorption onto the Al3+ acidic sites on the catalyst surface. The adjacent oxygen atom with Al3+ can be considered as base sites, that is AlO acid-base pair, and the IPA is adsorbed on O2– of the AlO acid-base pair (step I). Secondly, the IPA molecule is deprotonated to form an alkoxy intermediate (negatively charged), and FAL forms a COAl3+ bond at the Lewis acid site (Step II). Thirdly, the transition state (six-membered ring) is formed by coordination between the CO bond in the alkoxy group of IPA and the CO bond in the FAL (step III), and then the α-H in the IPA is transferred to the carbonyl carbon in the FAL (step IV). Finally, the dehydrogenation product acetone and hydrogenation product FOL are formed and released (step V). In summary, an appropriate adding amount of Zn can tune the acidity and basicity of the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst, promoting the dehydrogenation of IPA to form active hydrogen donors and the coordination of Al3+ active sites with CHO functional groups of FAL to produce FOL. In situ formation of carbon enhances the dispersion of active Al3+–O2- acid-base pair and the adsorption of FAL, promoting the mass transfer rate. Additionally, the appropriate acid/base ratio can inhibit the occurrence of side reactions such as acetal reaction and etherification reaction, thereby improving the yield and selectivity of the target FOL product. 4 Conclusion To summarize, we have developed a novel, straightforward, and efficient method for preparing composite ZnxAlOy-C catalysts. Their catalytic activities were evaluated using the CTH of FAL to FOL as a model reaction, with IPA acting as both hydrogen donor and solvent. The findings demonstrate that the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst can achieve a FAL conversion of 92.0 % and an FOL selectivity of 93.8 % under N2 atmosphere at 170 °C for 3 h. A series of experiments and characterizations confirm that the synergistic effect of the acid-base sites in the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst is crucial for the excellent CTH reaction of FAL to FOL·NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, and in-situ FT-IR studies indicate that the main active site in the Zn2AlOy-C catalyst is Al2O3, where trivalent aluminum not only promotes the graphitization of glucose but also provides Lewis acid-base sites. The Lewis acidity and basicity of pure Al2O3 are quite strong, and by adjusting the Zn/Al ratio, an appropriate acid-base ratio can be found to the optimal catalytic activity. The in-situ formed carbon layer on the catalyst enhances the dispersion of the active sites and the adsorption capacity for reactants, facilitating the adsorption and transfer of reactants from the solution to the active sites. This research presents an easy approach to making metal oxide catalysts and gives deep insights on the mechanism of CTH reactions under acid-base synergistic catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenation (CTH) has been widely reported as an efficient, safe and green method for catalytic hydrogenation of biomass-derived platform molecules in recent years. In this work, we fabricated tunable Zn/Al molar ratio carbon-coated hydrotalcite-derived Zn-Al oxide composites (ZnxAlOy-C), where Isopropanol (IPA) served dual roles as hydrogen donor and reaction medium, to achieve selective hydrogenation of Furfural (FAL) into Furfuryl Alcohol (FOL). Under mild reaction conditions, the conversion of FAL and the selectivity of FOL can reach 92.0% and 93.8% over Zn2AlOy-C, respectively. Through analysis, the reasons for the high yield of FOL are that the surface carbon material effectively increases the specific surface area of the catalyst, enhances the adsorption capacity of the catalyst to the reactants, and more effectively promotes the migration of the reactants from the solution to the Zn-O-Al active site, while by adjusting the Zn/Al ratio, a suitable acid/base ratio is found to reduce the occurrence of side reactions and improve the selectivity. The current synthesis method provides an effective way to design carbon-containing composite catalysts with controllable catalytic application performance.

coredata.dc:title: In situ engineering carbon-coated hydrotalcite-derived ZnxAlOy-C catalysts for efficient catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol
